awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Managing Patient Flows with Congestion Effects
awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to develop simple and effective dynamic control policies to improve hospital patient flows with a primary focus on the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). ICUs provide care for the most critical patients. They are very expensive to operate and often operate at or above capacity. Variability in patient flows from the Emergency Department (ED) and other inpatient units can exacerbate congestion in the ICU; this can alter the type and quality of care provided. There has been significant effort from the medical community to reduce process variation; however, in general, they have not considered how operational factors may contribute to this variation.  The research will use operations research tools to improve patient flows by augmenting traditional models and introducing new ones which account for congestion effects.  

The results of this research will generate insight for how congestion affects the timing of care and, subsequently, impacts the best practices for healthcare operations in the ICU and other care facilities. Such quantitative modeling and optimization will provide the foundation for systematic decision making. Close collaborations with clinicians will help facilitate exposure and acceptance of operational tools by the medical community. Adoption of these policies and methodologies will help improve patient outcomes via increased access to care and may also reduce hospital costs. This has important implications for improvement of healthcare provision and is of direct impact to patients and the wider community.

por.por_cntn:
Hospital care comprises over 30% of healthcare expenditures in the United States. Patient flow through hospitals, and particularly Intensive Care Units (ICU), can be significantly impacted by the amount of congestion in the hospital units. This project utilized statistical tools and mathematical models to inform the impact of congestion on patient flow and to derive insights into strategies to effectively manage limited resources. The project involved collaborations with and patient flow data from Northern California Kaiser Permanente and NY Presbyterian Hospitals to develop an understanding of congestion effects on patient flow and patient outcomes. We find statistically significant evidence that congestion can restrict access to care and result in worse outcomes (e.g. increase mortality risk or length-of-stay). For instance, delayed admission to the ICU is associated with increased length-of-stay. Ignoring such effects can result in very poor operational decision making, with the potential to jeopardize quality of care. These dynamics introduce the need for new models for capacity management.  Indeed, by incorporating such congestion effects and consequences in operational models, we are able to better understand how to determine bed capacity to avoid severe under provisioning.  The results of this project include the development of better capacity management tools and resource allocation strategies which have the potential to improve patient outcomes such as reduced mortality rates, lengths-of-stay, and/or readmission rates. A small pilot implementation of one of the nurse staffing algorithms developed through this project suggests such approaches could significantly improve patient flow in the Emergency Department. This research opens up interesting new areas of exploration into the implementation of such approaches in practice and the potential benefit to hospitalized patients.
